critique: This document is an executive order regarding land use in Alaska in 1937. It transfers small parcels of land from the Tongass National Forest to private individuals for homesites. Given the context of the time, this likely reflects a policy of encouraging settlement and resource development in Alaska. It is difficult to assess the ideological tilt without more context, but it seems to favor individual property rights and limited government control over land. The order does not directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security, economic regulation, or social inclusion. Therefore, most of these axes will be scored as neutral. The action of transferring land out of federal control could be seen as a slight move towards deregulation.
